report_title: Home Furnishings Stores in the US Industry Report
executive_summary: Home furnishing stores sell various home furnishing products, including kitchenware, textiles, appliances, fixtures and decorative pieces. Industry revenue has been bolstered in recent years by a steady climb in both disposable income and housing starts. However, revenue growth has been constrained because of heightened competition and lockdowns restricting in-store shopping during the pandemic. Revenue is expected to climb at a CAGR of 1.7% to $69.5 billion through the end of 2024, including growth of 2.2% in 2024 alone. Meanwhile, profitability has diminished because of growing competition from online retailers and discount stores.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Demand in Response to Strong Construction Markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Demand for home furnishings has improved as consumers have bought new homes. Remodeling and renovation activity has also trended upward in recent years, which has boosted revenue. Consumers typically visit home furnishings stores when moving into a new place or renovating their current living situation.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: E-commerce Poses a Threat to Brick-and-Mortar Stores
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: E-commerce sales have also been on the rise, which creates a major hurdle for home furnishing stores that focus on their brick-and-mortar operations. Despite the promising numbers for other key factors, e-commerce is the single largest threat to traditional stores.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Department Stores Offer More Convenience to Consumers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Discount department stores have lured customers away from specialist home furnishing stores by offering lower prices and the convenience of one-stop shopping. While many furnishings stores retail a selection limited to industry-relevant goods, department stores allow consumers to shop for a wide range of products in one location.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Furnishings Sales Grow When Consumers Want To Change Their Spaces
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Home improvement projects can range from DIY décor projects to replacing the floor of a space. When economic conditions are less favorable, consumers become more likely to use home furnishing to change the look of space at a lower cost.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition Will Remain A Threat Moving Forward
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite rising demand for home furnishings, pressures from external competitors will remain high. Home furnishings stores have had to contend with rising pressure from large department stores and online retailers, in particular.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition from upscale brands will increase in the coming years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As disposable income increases, many consumers will be willing to spend more on luxury purchases. This trend has become more prominent as consumers have become more infatuated with trendy brands. Consumers have shown a willingness to pay a significant premium for these products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Uncertainty Will Dampen Growth Prospects
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The economic volatility and uncertainty caused by geopolitical tensions, trade disputes and fluctuating interest rates will pose challenges to the growth of home furnishings stores in the US.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation Activity Gives Opportunities To Stores
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Larger home furnishings stores will continue to expand, pushing market concentration upward. By consolidating to establish more efficient operations, stores can better compete with large department stores and online retailers. Merging with rivals can also combine synergies and improve buying power.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Stores Continue to Contend with Volatile Input Prices
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Retailers will continue being impacted by volatile input prices. The costs for synthetic fibers, plastic materials and wood are expected to continue rising over the coming years, making furnishings more expensive and pushing purchase costs higher.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry retail a range of home furnishing goods, including curtains, draperies, blinds, shades, kitchenware, outdoor furniture, home and personal care appliances, floor coverings and decorative accessories. Merchandise is purchased from manufacturers and wholesalers and then sold to the public. Retailers that operate primarily as furniture stores, flooring stores or electronic shopping and mail-order houses are not included in this industry.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Consumer confidence index

key_trends: Big-box retailers and tech giants like Amazon have changed the game. These sectors have made it challenging for smaller brick-and-mortar stores to compete in price, product offerings and convenience.
Stores price products to maximize returns and stay competitive. Consumers prefer low prices, often found at large retailers that have achieved economies of scale, boosting price-based competition.

Revenue growth is slowing due to elevated inflation, high interest rates and weak macroeconomic conditions. While demand for new home furnishings is growing, these unfavorable economic factors are causing consumers to cut discretionary purchases, harming retailers.

Big names like Walmart and Target attract budget-conscious, time-poor shoppers. These stores offer a wide variety of products and will continue to challenge specialized home furnishing stores moving forward.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers in the lowest income quintile are expected to earn an average of about $16,000.00 annually, with $31,000.00 being the upper limit. Despite having the least amount of disposable income among the consumer markets, these consumers are expected to account for about one-fifth of revenue and represent the third-largest downstream market. Consumers in this income bracket have less access to high-end products and instead replace broken or outdated goods.

Consumers in the second quintile earn an average of about $45,000.00 annually, with an upper limit of $60,000.00. The second-largest market, consumers in this income bracket represent more than a quarter of total revenue. Similar to the lowest quintile, these consumers typically buy less costly goods that need to be replaced or repaired more often.
Consumers in this market earn an average of $79,000.00 annually, with $100,000.00 being the upper limit.

Consumers in the fourth quintile earn an average of $130,000.00 annually, with an upper limit of about $150,000.00. As the single largest market, this demographic is expected to represent nearly one-third of revenue.
Consumers in the top quintile receive an average salary of more than $300,000.00, with no upper limit.
Within this category, retail outlets represent the largest downstream market, followed by wholesalers and businesses.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment is composed of lamps, lampshades, mirrors, pictures and picture frames, posters, clocks, vases and candles. It also includes decorative items for special occasions like Christmas, Halloween and Valentine's Day.
Products in this category tend to be costly. Curtains and blinds are used as decorations and also to reduce sunlight and provide additional privacy in homes.
Products include pots, pans, baking supplies, small kitchen electronics, fans, space heaters and other related products.
Textile products include towels, sheets, blankets, table linens and coverings.
Although the industry excludes retailers that specifically retail furniture, some furnishing stores offer furniture as part of their product offerings.
This segment includes items like luggage, apparel and accessories, pet care items and all other miscellaneous merchandise that is not classified into the aforementioned categories.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The Consumer Confidence Index (CCI) measures the level of consumer optimism toward economic conditions, including unemployment, economic growth and inflation.
Per capita disposable income refers to the income consumers can spend on goods and services.
As consumers spend more on home improvements, home furnishings stores will also benefit.
Housing starts measure the number of new privately owned housing unit builds started.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the largest population, driving more foot traffic to stores in the region.
The West holds a substantial portion of the US population, which reduces transportation costs due to proximity to downstream consumers.
The Mid-Atlantic benefits from having the highest per capita disposable income in the United States.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act (CPSIA) imposes strict safety standards.
The Consumer Products Safety Commission (CPSC) laws impact furnishings stores by requiring compliance with safety standards.
The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) mandates that stores ensure accessibility for individuals with disabilities.
The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) significantly impacts home furnishings stores by stipulating minimum wage rates.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The home furnishings sector is in a mature life cycle stage.
The competition level in the industry is high and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Big-box retailers and tech giants like Amazon have changed the game, making it challenging for smaller brick-and-mortar stores to compete in price, product offerings and convenience.
Stores price products to maximize returns and stay competitive.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Stores serving their local markets keep concentration low.
Significant external competition prevents specialized furnishings stores from growing.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: THE NEED FOR HUMAN LABOR KEEPS WAGES HIGH
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Home furnishings stores rely heavily on employees for daily operations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PURCHASE PRICES HAVE REMAINED HIGH AND STEADY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include items sold in the store, displays for store merchandise and other items.

volatility_points.volatility_title: STORES EXHIBIT A MODERATE LEVEL OF VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Home furnishings stores exhibit a moderate level of revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE CONTRIBUTES TO REVENUE VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: In recent years, growth in per capita disposable income has enabled consumers to spend more at home furnishings stores.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Most of the technological improvements for home furnishings stores enable better management of operations and inventory.

FAQs.question: Do your company's advertising campaigns target a wide range of consumers? Do your products span multiple product segments?
FAQs.answer: Some companies target specific groups of consumers, limiting their customer reach but attracting a very niche group of people.

FAQs.question: How has your business adapted to the growth of online sales over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Some companies have opened online stores to remain competitive, but this has reduced brick-and-mortar sales.
